dayInfo.description: London - New York. Fly from London to Buffalo. Today you begin your journey by boarding your international outbound flight to Buffalo. You arrive in Buffalo this morning collect your hire car and head to nearby Niagara Falls where the remainder of the evening is free to explore at your leisure.

Niagara Falls. Spend the day exploring the flower-adorned streets of this historic town. You may wish to take a stroll along the lake-side parklands or visit the Canada`s pretty town of Niagara on the Lake. This afternoon you are booked onto the Maid of the Mist boat tour, which will take you right up to the falls for a spectacular view!

Niagara Falls - Ithaca. Depart the falls at your leisure today and head south east to New York State`s Finger Lakes region. The afternoon is free to take a boat trip on the lake, hire a bicycle or explore the shops and restaurants along the waters edge.

Ithaca. Enjoy a full day exploring the wonderful Finger Lakes today. We recommend a visit to Buttermilk Falls State Park where you will find more than 10 waterfalls tumbling some 500ft below into clear pools. In the afternoon why not head to Corning, home to the impressive Cornell University as well as the massive Corning Museum of Glass.
Ithaca - Clayton, New York. Leave the Finger Lakes and head to the wonderful 1000 Islands area where you will be based for the next few nights.

Clayton, New York. Enjoy a full day of activity in 1000 Islands. You may wish to take in some excellent kayaking on the St. Lawrence River or perhaps head to Wellesley Island State Park and enjoy some bike riding.

Clayton, New York - North River. Leave the river today and head into the largest wilderness in the US, the Adirondack Park. Head to your lodge in the heart of the park where the afternoon is free to explore the local area.
North River. Enjoy a full day of walking, cycling, kayaking and exploring some of the best scenery in the US.

North River - Lake Placid. Continue north today as you head to the site of two winter Olympics, Lake Placid. Upon arrival to your hotel overlooking the impressive scenery of Mirror Lake, spend the afternoon exploring at your leisure.

Lake Placid. Mirror Lake and Lake Placid are at your disposal today as you spend a full day in the area. You can kayak on the waters, swim in the shallow outer parts or just relax on the beach. The nearby mountains are great for gentle hiking and afford spectacular views over the region.
Lake Placid - New York City. It is a simple drive today and your head south to the state capital, Albany. Here you take the train for a scenic rail journey into New York City.

New York City. You will have all day to explore Manhattan at your leisure today. Visit any of of New York's famous attractions within walking distance of your hotel; the Statue of Liberty, Madison Square Garden, the Rockefeller Center and the Empire State building. In the afternoon you can wonder the windy paths of Central Park for a lovely respite from the 'hustle and bustle' of the city.

New York City. Today you will meet your guide in the Flatiron district for your walking culinary tour of this lesser known part of the city. The tour focuses on architecture as well as food as you walk through the historic district. This afternoon you may wish to visit Chelsea, where you can visit the famous market or walk the high line, an elevated public garden built on a disused railway track.
You have most of the day free for one last stroll around The Big Apple before heading to the airport for your onward flight.

tourName: New York to Boston, small group tour
generalInfo:
Our East Coast America group tour takes in some of the nation's most iconic cities as well as stepping off the beaten track into coastal splendour.

Discover the majesty of these East Coast cities- from the fascinating history of Boston, to the spell-binding skyline of N.Y.C, to the imposing grandeur of Washington D.C.

We’ll show you the unmissable sights that make these places famous but also offer experiences to really understand how these places tick - there’s a whole lot more than just the star-studded attractions. Plus- we’ll venture out of the cities with stops on the coast, countryside and even the ocean.

dayInfo.description: Boston: Welcome to the USA and the start of your East Coast adventure! Spend the morning exploring Boston at your leisure, then meet your Adventure Leader and group in the afternoon at the entrance of HI Boston hostel. Here, you'll get to know your fellow travelers and receive a trip briefing, where you’ll learn about the exciting journey ahead and safety tips for your time in the U.S. Your first adventure kicks off with a walk along Boston’s historic 2.5-mile Freedom Trail, which connects 16 nationally significant landmarks. Along the way, you’ll see sights like Park Street Church, Boston Common (the oldest public park in the U.S.), Faneuil Hall, and the North End, Boston's famous 'Little Italy.' Don't miss the chance to grab a world-renowned cannoli at Mike’s Pastry! Next, we’ll hop on the T (Boston’s subway) to visit Fenway Park, home of the Red Sox. If the team is playing at home, your tour of the park will be swapped for tickets to a live game (this happens about 50% of the time)! The evening is free for you to explore. Stay in the Fenway area for a fun night of vintage bowling or head to a nearby bar for live stand-up comedy. The night is yours!

New York: Today, we’re heading to the Big Apple! We’ll start early and catch a bus to New York City. After arriving, we’ll head to the HI New York Hostel to check in before kicking off your first adventure in the city—a thrilling speedboat ride on “The Beast.” We’ll zoom across New York Harbor, offering unforgettable views of the iconic Statue of Liberty. After returning to dry land, it’s time to indulge at Chelsea Market, a famous food hall with everything from seafood and tacos to artisanal baked goods. You’ll be spoiled for choice! As evening approaches, we’ll head to the Rockefeller Center. The Top of the Rock observatory, located on the 70th floor, provides breathtaking 360-degree views of New York City. Afterwards, enjoy the rest of the night at Times Square, where you can shop, sightsee, or just take in the dazzling lights.

New York: Start the day with a leisurely walk through Central Park, taking in famous landmarks like Bethesda Fountain and Belvedere Castle. Then, visit the renowned MET (Metropolitan Museum of Art) for a guided tour of its extraordinary exhibits, ranging from ancient artifacts to modern masterpieces. Next, embark on the No Sleep ‘Til Brooklyn tour, where you’ll discover the beauty of Brooklyn Heights, DUMBO, and Brooklyn Bridge Park. After a scenic lunch at Timeout Market, walk across the historic Brooklyn Bridge and learn about its fascinating history. Later, explore the trendy Williamsburg neighborhood, known for its street art, vintage shops, and outdoor bars. The evening is yours to enjoy, whether you choose to catch a Broadway show, visit the 9/11 Memorial, or attend one of New York’s many free events. Make the most of your last night in the city!

Philadelphia: Transfer to Philadelphia by train in the morning. If you’re craving something sweet, grab a cupcake to-go from Magnolia Bakery before departing. After arriving at the Apple Hostel, indulge in an authentic Philly Cheesesteak—a meal you won’t forget! Take some time to relax at the hostel or head out for a quick visit to see Liberty Bell and the Declaration of Independence. As evening falls, get ready to snap iconic photos on the steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art (made famous by the Rocky movies), then enjoy a night out in the trendy Fishtown district.

Washington DC: Rise and shine! Today, we travel to Washington DC by train. Arriving just in time for lunch, we’ll check into U-Street Hostel before setting off on a Washington Revelations walking tour, covering the city’s most famous landmarks, including the United States Capitol, the National Museum of African American History and Culture, the Washington Monument, The White House, and several historic memorials. For dinner, we’re heading to Ben’s Chili Bowl, a DC staple famously recommended by President Obama. Afterward, celebrate your last night on the East Coast with drinks in Adams Morgan or hit the lively U Street for an unforgettable night out.

Washington DC: Today marks the end of your East Coast America Adventure, so it’s time to say goodbye to all your new friends. If you’re not quite done with the USA East Coast you may want to stay an extra night in Washington D.C. Let us know and our team will able to assist you with an additional night’s accommodation.

tourName: New York to San Francisco tour in America
generalInfo:
Our America tour is packed with a whole series of hands-on activities and experiences that bring to life this fascinating nation. We travel to the big cities and spend time amidst the remote natural wonder.

Each day offers a different slice of Americana as we make our way from the big cities of the East Coast, the glitz of Vegas to the chilled out vibes of California via some fantastic stop offs.

Our adventure leaders will bring to life the places that we visit and we have a whole loads of experience beyond the standard tourist sights. For foodies- America offers up a whole series of treats and we'll be sure to sample the local cuisine across the trip.

We stay in a mixture of accommodation with city centre hostels, a luxury hotel in Las Vegas.

Allow us to let you discover America on this action-packed and exciting tour!

dayInfo.description: Welcome to the USA!: Your group tour across the USA begins! If you have time this morning, opt to go whale watching, spotting humpbacks and other marine life in their native feeding grounds off Cape Cod. In the afternoon, meet your travel crew and Adventure Leader for a quick briefing and head straight out! We’ll cross the Charles River to Cambridge to explore Harvard University. Wander the historic campus, browse the bookshops, peek into the art museum, and treat yourself to a world-famous Mike’s Pastry cannoli. Back in town, walk a stretch of the Freedom Trail, ticking off must-see historic sites along the way, then head to Quincy Market or the North End for dinner. The evening is yours to enjoy. If the Red Sox are playing, feel the buzz at the legendary Fenway Park, or join a spooky ghost tour or end the night with some laughs at one of Boston’s top comedy clubs. Boston: Done. On to the next adventure tomorrow!

NYC Bound, The Statue of Liberty & Brooklyn Bridge: Next stop, New York City! The Big Apple awaits! Once you’re ready for the day, take a short walk to the station and board your bus. Once you arrive in the city, fuel up with lunch by Madison Square Garden, dining in the shadow of the Empire State Building like a true New Yorker. Then hop on the subway to your accommodation to drop your bags and jump straight into the city. Head downtown to tick off the must-see highlights of the Financial District. Snap those iconic shots with the Charging Bull and Fearless Girl, roam the historic streets, and pause at the powerful 9/11 Memorial. After that, it’s time to crank things up: jump aboard The Beast, NYC’s high-speed thrill boat, for incredible views of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Manhattan skyline, and a Statue of Liberty photo that makes everyone at home jealous. Cross the river to explore Brooklyn Heights and DUMBO, two of the most scenic (and Instagram-famous) corners of the city. Chill in Brooklyn Bridge Park, toss a frisbee around, and grab a slice of pizza that locals swear rivals Naples. Tonight is yours – shop and snack your way through SoHo, Chinatown, or Little Italy, or embrace the full neon madness of Times Square.

Central Park, Rockefeller Centre & Discover Brooklyn: Today we’re fully entering our New York City era. Start your morning in Central Park, discovering why it’s the most filmed location on the planet. Think bridges, lakes, movie moments, and main character energy! From there, stroll through the iconic Fifth Avenue, soaking in all the glamour from the Plaza Hotel to St. Patrick’s Cathedral. Next, get ready for sky high magic at the Top of the Rock. The 360 degree views from the 70th floor of Rockefeller Centre are unreal and yes, you’ll want photos from every angle. Since it is Taco Tuesday, enjoy a festive group lunch at a favourite taqueria. After that, swing by Grand Central Terminal for a Magnolia cupcake or simply stand there staring at the ceiling thinking wow New York really does the most. This afternoon, we’ll head to Bushwick, home to bold street art, quirky vintage shops, and some of the coolest bars in the city. Trust us – every corner here is a photo op! Tonight is yours. Wander through Williamsburg for indie charm and good eats or score a last minute Broadway ticket because why not end your day in true NYC fashion.

Washington DC Bound, Lafayette Park & Georgetown: Back to Washington DC we go, arriving just in time for lunch at Ben’s Chili Bowl, one of Obama’s all time favourites! Grab a classic chili bowl and get ready for an afternoon of iconic sights. First stop: Arlington National Cemetery. Expect a peaceful, respectful atmosphere as you visit powerful sites like the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, JFK’s eternal flame, and Arlington House overlooking the city. Next, it is photo time at the world’s most famous address, 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. From Lafayette Park, you’ll get that classic, straight on view of the White House, perfect for your camera roll. Then take a spooky detour to Georgetown’s famous Exorcist Stairs for a fun photo moment before enjoying some free time in Georgetown. Explore historic spots, stroll the waterfront, rent a kayak, go skating in winter, or head to the shops along M Street and Wisconsin Avenue.

Washington Revelations & The Evening Your Way: Today you’re seeing the very best of DC on the Washington Revelations tour. Think big, iconic landmarks like the United States Capitol, the Library of Congress, the National Museum of the American Indian, the Air and Space Museum, the Natural History Museum, the African American Museum, the Washington Monument, and even the Lincoln and Martin Luther King Jr. Memorials. It is DC at its absolute finest! For your final night on the East Coast, celebrate together with a night out on lively U Street or in the trendy bars and music spots of Adams Morgan.

Welcome to Las Vegas!: This morning, we fly west to Las Vegas! After landing, you’ll transfer to your hotel on the iconic Strip before meeting your Adventure Leader and group at the Luxor Hotel’s Aurora Bar. You’ll meet some new travel buddies, get the low-down on the days ahead, and hear all the tips you need to stay safe and have the time of your life on the west coast. Then it’s time to hit the Strip! Soak up the electric energy, neon lights, and non-stop buzz of Las Vegas before sitting down for a group meal at Café Hollywood – a retro American diner with all the classics. Afterwards, enjoy the legendary Bellagio Water Show, where towering fountains burst into life with music and light – a true Vegas icon and star of countless movies. For those who love a night out, you’re in good hands! Our local Adventure Leaders can point you towards some of Vegas’s best nightlife…

Route 66 Legends, Seligman, & Campfire S’mores in Arizona: This morning, you’ll hit the road for the next stop – but not before ticking off a couple of absolute icons. First up: the legendary Las Vegas sign, before stopping at Trader Joe’s – LA’s favourite grocery store – to load up on snacks and supplies for the day, then it’s onwards to Route 66! Lunch offers a couple of fun options! Opt for a chilled Trader Joe’s picnic at Locomotive Park in Kingman, Arizona, home to the mighty Steam Engine #3759. This historic beauty was gifted to the city back in 1957 by the Santa Fe Railway Company, and you can even climb aboard for a closer look. Alternatively, choose to grab a classic Route 66 meal at the colourful and retro Mr. D’z Route 66 Diner just steps away. Next, we’ll visit the rustic Seligman – the birthplace of Route 66 and the real-life inspiration behind Pixar’s Cars. Wander around, soak up the retro Americana vibes, and grab some iconic snaps before hopping back on the bus bound for Williams. Tonight, you’ll check into an incredible glamping site, settling into your cosy cabin before heading out for a BBQ dinner with your travel buddies at the Cruiser’s Route 66 Café. Afterwards, it’s back to the campsite to gather around the fire and tuck into the ultimate road-trip treat: s’mores, of course!

Grand Canyon, South Rim Trail, & Vegas Sightseeing!: This morning, we’re heading straight for one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World and a mega highlight of your adventure – the Grand Canyon! You’ll have time to soak up the sheer scale of this 277-mile masterpiece, snap some epic shots along the South Rim, and hit one of the many unforgettable trails. If you’re after a recommendation, the Rim Trail is a winner – take it at your own pace and don’t forget to pack plenty of water! By mid-afternoon, we’ll meet back at the Hopi House next to the historic El Tovar Hotel before hopping on the bus and cruising back to Vegas. The evening’s all yours to explore with your group! Some suggestions on how to spend your evening in Las Vegas from our local experts are: -For the arts lovers… Wander the vibrant Arts District, packed with street murals, indie galleries, and unique local spots. -For the music fans… head to Fremont Street in Downtown Las Vegas, where you’ll find plenty of live music concerts (most of them for free too)! -For the ever-so-slightly crazy… try Nacho Daddy’s Scorpion Shot, a masterful blend of tasty spirits and exotic ingredients, topped off with a real, edible scorpion (yep, you heard right). -For the history buffs… Explore the MOB Museum (approx. $27.95), filled with gripping stories of America’s criminal underworld. This is a nonprofit organisation with a mission to advance the public understanding of organized crime’s history and impact on American society. -For the neon nerds… Visit the iconic Neon Museum (from apprx. $36.23) an outdoor experience that brings the story of Las Vegas to life, where you’ll find spaces, signs and experiences that bring our rich history to light. Please note: Reservations are required in advance and can be booked with the help of your Adventure Leader. -For the fandom fanatics… Pop into Fandom Bar, the go-to spot for lovers of all things fantasy and sci-fi.

Santa Monica Sightseeing & Sunset Beach Stroll: This morning, we’re off to the next stop on your USA tour – Los Angeles! Transfer by bus to arrive in Santa Monica in the early afternoon where your Adventure Leader will meet you, before checking into the Santa Monica hostel. You’ll have some free time to wander the iconic 3rd Street Promenade at your own pace – think street performers, cool shops, and laid-back Cali vibes. When hunger strikes, grab dinner wherever takes your fancy; your Adventure Leader will have plenty of top local recommendations for you! As the evening sets in, we’ll regroup for an unmissable activity: a sunset stroll along Santa Monica Beach followed by an arcade challenge on the legendary Santa Monica Pier!

Sunset Boulevard & Griffith Observatory at Sunset: This morning, we’re hitting the heart of LA! Take the metro to the iconic Sunset Boulevard and stroll among the stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. For lunch, we’ll all grab a classic California treat together with a group meal at In-N-Out Burger, before enjoying some free time to explore – maybe the Hollywood Film Museum, the Wax Museum, or a spot of souvenir shopping. In the early evening, get ready for an unmissable adventure: a hike from Griffith Park up to the legendary Griffith Observatory! Along the way, snap epic views of the Hollywood sign and arrive just in time to watch the sun dip behind the City of Angels. As you make your way back down, the city lights will sparkle below – a true main-character moment – before returning to your Santa Monica hostel.

Beach Volleyball Lesson, Flight to San Fran, & Yosemite Bug: This morning, we’re up and at ‘em with another unmissable activity: volleyball on Santa Monica beach! Your group will get your very own coach and learn how to bump, set, and spike. Then, it’s time to transfer to the final stop on the west coast – San Fran! We’ll head to the airport and take a speedy flight from LA to San Francisco. Touch down in San Francisco and meet your Adventure Leader, who’ll whisk you straight into the wild beauty of Yosemite country. Settle into the beautiful Yosemite Bug Mountain Resort – a cosy, rustic base surrounded by epic forests, fresh alpine air, and the unmistakable magic of Yosemite on your doorstep. As evening settles in, gather with your group for a tasty meal at the June Bug Café, then head up the mountain for some incredible stargazing. With the Milky Way overhead and Yosemite’s wilderness around you, it’s the perfect way to kick off your time in one of America’s most legendary landscapes.

Columbia Rock Hike & Merced River Plunge: This morning, we’ll check out of Yosemite Bug Resort and hop on the YARTS bus straight into the heart of Yosemite National Park for an unmissable day of adventure. With your expert guide, you’ll take on the rewarding hike up to Columbia Rock along the Yosemite Falls Trail, where sweeping Sierra Nevada views make every step worth it! Don’t worry, we’ll stop and refuel with a picnic lunch beneath towering cliffs and pine forests, then cool off with an exhilarating plunge into the Merced River – the perfect way to wrap up your Yosemite experience. In the afternoon, ride the YARTS bus back to the resort, grab your bags, and hit the road to San Francisco, stopping for dinner en route before checking into your hostel for a well-earned rest.

Bike ride across Golden Gate Bridge & Optional Alcatraz Island Tour: We kick off our final day with an absolute must-do: a bike ride across the legendary Golden Gate Bridge! Spend the morning cycling past some of San Francisco’s most iconic sights, taking in the views and snapping those postcard-perfect shots, before rolling back to Pier 39. Sadly, this marks the end of your tour across the USA! But if you’re up for one last adventure, you can opt to hop on a ferry to the infamous Alcatraz Island and explore ‘The Rock’ for a glimpse inside the legendary prison. Still sticking around for the evening? Let’s make it a night to remember – ride a cable car to Union Square, catch a Giants baseball game, or just soak up the buzzing San Fran nightlife one last time!

tourName: Oregon self drive holiday, USA
generalInfo: Discover Oregon's Best Adventure: 8 nights of family fun! From Crater Lake to the Columbia River Gorge, enjoy private tours, rock climbing, and stargazing. Start with the scenic Oregon Coast, indulge in local delights, then sip on pinots in Willamette Valley. Get your adrenaline pumping with rock climbing at Smith Rock State Park. Explore Crater Lake and its wonders. Traverse lava caves and stargaze while canoeing. Dive into Mount Hood and the Columbia River Gorge's ecological diversity. Depart with cherished memories of Oregon's beauty.

dayInfo.description: Start your Oregon adventure by landing at Portland International Airport, where the stunning landscapes of the Oregon Coast beckon. Rent a car at the airport to embark on your scenic journey. Enjoy a picturesque 1.5-hour drive to Cannon Beach, winding through the majestic Coastal mountain range. Along the way, consider making an optional stop in downtown Portland to soak in the city's vibrant atmosphere. Arrive at your accommodations nestled along the breathtaking coastline and settle in for a relaxing evening at your leisure, embracing the tranquility of the coastal charm.

Immerse yourself in the unparalleled beauty of the Oregon coast as you enjoy a day at your leisure. Delight your taste buds with mouthwatering delicacies like fresh fish and chips and decadent marionberry pie at charming seaside restaurants. Explore the intricate ecosystems of tide pools or embark on a scenic hike amidst the lush trees and sandy beaches of Ecola State Park. Need recommendations? Your dedicated guide is on hand to tailor suggestions to your preferences, ensuring an unforgettable coastal experience tailored just for you.

Indulge in a journey through the exquisite wineries nestled amidst the rolling hills of the Willamette Valley, renowned for its world-class pinot noirs. Immerse yourself in the sensory experience as you sip on these acclaimed wines, all while soaking in breathtaking panoramic views of endless vineyards from the inviting decks of each tasting room. Along the way, your knowledgeable guide will regale you with captivating tales of the valley's rich history and geology, enriching your wine-tasting adventure with fascinating insights. After a day of vinicultural delights, embark on a leisurely 3-hour drive southward to the vibrant city of Bend. Upon arrival, settle into your accommodations and relish in a tranquil evening, reflecting on the day's discoveries amidst the enchanting backdrop of Central Oregon.

Prepare for an exhilarating day of rock climbing in the iconic Smith Rock State Park, guided by a seasoned local expert. With its rugged terrain and thousands of climbing routes, Smith Rock promises an adventure like no other. Your guide will tailor the climbs to suit your skill level, ensuring a thrilling experience for both seasoned climbers and beginners alike. All necessary gear, including harnesses, shoes, helmets, and safety equipment, will be provided, leaving you free to focus on conquering the crags. As the sun sets on your day of adventure, unwind and explore the charming town of Bend at your own pace, immersing yourself in its scenic beauty and laid-back atmosphere.

Embark on an extraordinary journey to uncover the secrets of Crater Lake, a jewel nestled in the heart of Oregon and renowned as one of the purest lakes on Earth. Delve into the depths of our continent's deepest lake as you embark on a personalized hike crafted to match your interests and abilities. Your guide, a font of knowledge about the park's flora, fauna, and rich history, will whisk you away from Bend to Crater Lake, regaling you with captivating tales along the way. Prepare to be enraptured by the pristine beauty that surrounds you as you traverse the park's trails. Amidst this full-day adventure, indulge in a delectable packed lunch thoughtfully provided by your guide, ensuring you stay energized for the wonders that await.

Prepare for an enchanting day filled with natural wonders! Your adventure begins in the late morning with a small group tour, delving into the mysterious lava caves that dot Oregon's landscape. Led by your knowledgeable guide, unravel the geological history behind these mesmerizing formations, gaining insights into their creation and significance. As the day transitions into evening, get ready for a celestial experience like no other. Join a small group stargazing canoeing trip led by a local Oregon naturalist guide. Glide across the serene waters of a picturesque Cascade lake, your guide skillfully navigating the way. Beneath the vast expanse of the night sky, your guide will unveil the secrets of the stars, pointing out constellations and sharing fascinating stories of the cosmos as you drift along. Prepare to be captivated by the beauty of the universe, immersing yourself in a truly magical experience under the celestial canopy.

Bid farewell to the charming city of Bend as you embark on a northward journey towards the majestic Columbia River Gorge. Along the way, rendezvous with your expert guide for an exclusive exploration of the awe-inspiring Mount Hood, Oregon's highest peak. Marvel at the breathtaking vistas as you ascend the slopes of this iconic mountain, with your guide offering captivating insights into its geological and cultural significance. As the day unfolds, make a stop at the historic Timberline Lodge, a renowned landmark nestled amidst the alpine splendor. Indulge in a delightful dinner and refreshing drinks, savoring the rustic ambiance and panoramic views that surround you. With spirits lifted and memories cherished, continue your adventure towards Hood River, nestled within the verdant embrace of the Columbia River Gorge. Prepare to be enchanted by the scenic wonders that await as you bid adieu to another unforgettable day in the Pacific Northwest.

Embark on a picturesque journey along the Columbia River Gorge, a breathtaking landscape shaped by centuries of geological evolution. Your day will be filled with awe-inspiring stops including the iconic Crown Point Vista House, where panoramic views of the gorge unfold before your eyes, and the majestic Multnomah Falls, cascading in graceful tiers amidst lush greenery. As you traverse through this natural wonderland, your knowledgeable naturalist guide will illuminate the rich history and ecological significance of the area, unveiling its secrets and mysteries. Marvel at the diverse ecosystems thriving within the gorge, a testament to the resilience of nature against the forces of time and erosion. Amidst the exploration, indulge in a delightful picnic lunch at one of Hood River's charming local parks, surrounded by the serene beauty of the Columbia River. As you bask in the tranquility of your surroundings, savoring each moment, you'll come to appreciate the profound connection between nature and nourishment, leaving you with cherished memories of a day well spent in the heart of Oregon's wilderness.
It’s time to say “goodbye for now” to beautiful Oregon with memories to last a life time.

tourName: Rogue River rafting holiday in the USA
generalInfo:
In southern Oregon, not far from Crater Lake National Park and the California Redwoods the Rogue River flows through wild mountains on its way to the Pacific. Join us for the only rafting trip in the United States where can you raft a wilderness river by day and stay in a comfortable lodge each evening as you progress down the river! And if you prefer to hike, we also offer raft-supported hiking trips in May and June. We are one of a very few outfitters able to provide these Rogue River lodge-based trips due to our relationships with the exclusive lodges along the Rogue River.

The Rogue River is one of the most famous rivers in the American West. It flows from Oregon’s Cascade Mountains to the Pacific Ocean through the heart of the Rogue River Wilderness. There are fun, moderate rapids, warm water and a thick-forested canyon that make the Rogue River the perfect natural playground. During the day you raft on splashy rapids and in the quiet pools between, watch for wildlife such as deer, river otter, black bear, osprey, waterfowl and other birds that make this their home. Like all superb whitewater rafting trips, there is also plenty of variety throughout the journey including walks to waterfalls, swimming holes and historic homesteads. The river water is warm and makes for excellent swimming. Few rivers offer such a magical blend of activities and fun suitable for all ages.

The rapids on this river are perfect for all ages and the Rogue is a superb rafting adventure for families. There are many easy to intermediate rapids as well as famous ones like Rainie Falls and Blossom Bar that make for added excitement. If you’re feeling adventurous then try your hand in an inflatable kayak for added thrills.

The Rogue River was named by French fur trappers who came here in the early 19th century and had some quarrels with the local Indians of the area. The French called these Indians “les Coquins” which means “the Rogues” and named the river “La Riviere aux Coquins,” the Rogue River.

Our trips flow through the most remote and beautiful canyons of the Rogue River where the forest is alive with wildlife. We almost always see black bear, river otters and deer. Birdwatchers will want to keep their eyes out for osprey, great blue herons, and the majestic bald eagle that fishes the waters of the Rogue.

On these great American adventures you have a choice of riding in rafts powered by oars and rowed by our guides or; riding in a paddle raft where you are part of team and with your guide, paddle and navigate through the rapids or; paddling your own inflatable kayak. Usually people try all three craft during the trip. Each afternoon we arrive at a remote wilderness lodge that offers comfortable accommodations.

dayInfo.description: Located in southwestern Oregon there are several options for reaching the Rogue River. You can fly Medford, Oregon, just an hour from our meeting point. Or you may be starting your western United States holiday with a rental car. San Francisco is just six hours south, Portland, Oregon is four and a half hours north and Seattle, Washington is about seven hours north. It’s easy to combine this trip with a visit to the Oregon Coast, Crater Lake National Park and/or Redwoods National Park. We meet in the small town of Merlin, Oregon at a riverside lodge for an orientation meeting the evening before the trip to answer last minute questions. You receive your waterproof gear bags (one for every two people) to pack. Since we’re staying in lodges you need only bring some clothes and personal items. Tonight, dinner is on your own.

We greet you at 8:15am and then depart for the launch point just 15 minutes away by van. Once there we have a safety orientation and then fit you with the correct sized PFD (personal flotation device). Then it’s time to board the various craft we have - oar rafts, paddle rafts and inflatable kayaks. The river starts off gently, but soon we come to our first whitewater. Sometime before noon, we enter the Federally protected Wild & Scenic section of the Wild Rogue River at a rapid called Grave Creek. Typically we eat lunch the first day around the Class V rafting rapid called Rainey Falls (guests walk around this rapid). The afternoon sports several Class II and Class III rapids and we arrive at our evening’s accommodations, Black Bar Lodge around 4:30 or 5:00pm. While you are being assigned to your cabin and cleaning up, we prepare hors d’oeuvres that are served with regional wine and beer for you to enjoy before dinner. You may want to take a short hike around the property, visit with your fellow rafters, or play some games offered at the lodge. About 7:00pm a family-style dinner is served in the cozy lodge dining room. After dinner, you can play cards, visit, strum the lodge guitar or go outside and gaze at a star-filled sky. Around 10:00pm the Black Bar Lodge's generator is shut down, so a flashlight is handy as the property can get very dark. Accommodations: Black Bar Lodge. Meals Included: Lunch, Dinner.

Coffee and tea is served in the lodge dining room followed by breakfast around 7:30. After breakfast we pack up and carry our gear back to the rafts and then launch about 9:00 am for another great day of exploring and fun. Today on your Oregon Rogue River rafting holiday you travel through a series of bouncing, exciting Class II and III rapids. We stop for lunch somewhere along the way, perhaps at a historic site or spot with a good walk. As the day continues we arrive at the Rogue River Ranch, a fascinating place to visit and a vivid example of early American pioneer history. Later in the afternoon we arrive at Marial Lodge to spend our second night. Once again, guests are assigned cabins and there’s time for a walk before we serve our delicious hors d’ouvres and drinks. Our family-style dinner is served around 6:30pm and after dinner our guides lead guests on a lovely and very scenic hike down a trail that leads to a spectacular waterfall. With long summer evenings there’s also time to enjoy the deck with expansive views of the river canyon before heading to bed. Accommodations: Marial Lodge Meals Included: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner

Wake up to the sound of birdsong and quiet. Breakfast is served around 8:00am and afterwards we pack up and head to the river. The third day has some of the most spectacular rapids on the Rogue River. There’s plenty of laughter and excitement as we raft through Mule Creek Canyon followed by Blossom Bar and Devils Staircase rapids--all Class IV. Tonight we arrive at our final riverside lodge, Half Moon Bar Lodge. Accommodations: Half Moon Bar Lodge Meals Included: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner

The rest of the trip takes us through relatively easy Class II and III white water. When the sun is high overhead we find a shady spot for another bountiful lunch. There are a few more rapids and more peaceful and beautiful scenery before we reach our take-out at Foster Bar. We aim to arrive at the take-out by 3:00pm and then load up into vans for a two-hour drive over the mountains back to our starting point. In the autumn, also offer a 4-day camping version of this same adventure. At this time of year the lodges are filled with fishing trips and the beaches and camps on the Rogue are scarcely used, making ideal conditions for our trips. Meals Included: Breakfast, Lunch

tourName: Salmon River rafting holiday in Idaho, USA
generalInfo:
The Middle Fork of the Salmon in Idaho is a legend and the finest alpine wilderness rafting trip in the world. The pure, clear, free-flowing river drops 3000-feet during its 100-mile journey through Idaho's remote and spectacular “River of No Return Wilderness” the largest wilderness area in the lower 48 states. Natural, wild and untamed, Idaho's Middle Fork is protected as one of America’s first Wild and Scenic Rivers. On this incredible wilderness rafting trip there are no roads and although this canyon was once home to gold miners and pioneers, little remains of man’s brief presence other than the pictographs of Native Americans and a few dilapidated log cabins.

We launch our boats at nearly 6,000 feet above sea level and immediately enter an verdant forest of fir and spruce. This is a steep river, at first shallow and narrow and filled with boulder-choked rapids. As each mile passes there are side creeks that tumble in and add to the Middle Fork's clear sparkling water. The whitewater rapids are frequent and challenging on the Middle Fork. Rafting guides speak their names with reverence - Ram's Horn, the Chutes, Marble Creek, Artillery, Devil's Tooth and House Rock to name just a few on this classic American West whitewater rafting trip.

As the river drops in elevation, the Middle Fork of the Salmon River widens and slows down a bit as the spruce forest opens up to a wider valley of pine-clad mountains. Our rafts drift quietly over deep pools of crystalline water—home to native cutthroat and rainbow trout. We stop often to visit nearby Native American pictographs and pioneer homesteads. Your guides share their knowledge of this story-filled canyon and use their skills to help draw the silent stories from these historic places.

Further on this rafting tour enters “Impassable Canyon” where granite mountains of staggering dimensions rise from the clear Middle Fork water high into a cobalt-blue Idaho sky. We stop at least twice a day for walks to special places and scenic wonders. Soaking in the many natural hot springs along the Middle Fork are highlights for many of our guests.

As we near the end of this life-changing Idaho rafting holiday, having dropped 3,000 feet in elevation and gained a lifetime of memories, it is hard not to envy the Native Americans and pioneers who spent their whole lives in the vast wild area that encompasses the Middle Fork of the Salmon River.

On these trips you have a choice of riding in rafts powered by oars, rowed by our guides while you enjoy the ride and take photos or; riding in a paddle raft where you are part of team paddling with your guide who gives commands or; the excitement of paddling your own inflatable kayak. We also have a cargo raft that travels ahead of the group along with two guides who set up a luxury camp including your tent, a complete kitchen with dining tables and chairs and more. The food that is served is fresh, bountiful and artfully prepared, packed in large ice coolers and using the best-available fresh ingredients.

In addition to rafting trips, we also have raft-supported hiking tours of this magnificent country. Load up a day pack with supplies to get you through the day, then hike to camp where you're gear will be waiting, tent set and food cooking.

dayInfo.description: This trip is accessed through Boise, Idaho which has air service from most major US carriers, often connecting through Salt Lake City, Denver or other major gateways. From Boise you continue to Stanley, Idaho by rented car or small air taxi. Below is a typical itinerary, but remember that every trip is unique. Water levels, as well as the campsites we are assigned by the U.S. Forest Service, vary week to week. This itinerary is meant to give you a snapshot of the trip but should not be considered an exact itinerary. Extreme high water or low water trips begin at Indian Creek—a 25-minute flight from Stanley, Idaho. You arrive in Stanley by 7:00pm MST to meet your lead guide for a one-hour orientation meeting. Any last-minute questions you have are answered and we give you your waterproof bags to pack with your gear for the trip. Dinner is on your own. You may want to schedule some time at the hotel’s private hot spring (reserve when checking in).

Meet at 7:30am for a two-hour bus ride to Boundary Creek and the start of our trip. At 6,000 feet elevation, the air is fresh and the forest thick with spruce, fir and pine. At the river’s edge we give a safety orientation while your personal gear is loaded onto the rafts. Then everyone chooses a raft (paddle or oar-powered) and climbs aboard. The first 15 miles of the Middle Fork are fast and rapids are steep, narrow and come in quick succession. During lunch, we give a talk to explain how we minimize our impact on the river with Leave No Trace camping techniques. Then after lunch the river continues to be spry and challenging. Every few hundred yards a creek crashes into the river, increasing the flow. We travel between 10 and 15 miles the first day and usually arrive at camp around 4:00pm. This gives you time to enjoy a hike, go fishing, reading or just relax. Hors d’oeuvres are served about 6:00 and dinner around 7:30. After dinner, a campfire is lit and the warmth naturally invites all to share stories of the day, and life.

We wake you up about 7:00am with coffee at your tent (or tea or hot chocolate). Breakfast is served and after, you pack up your personal gear. Rafts are loaded and we depart from camp for an adventure-filled day of rapids, magnificent scenery and plenty of plain old fun. We stop to visit visit one or two pioneer homesteads on these first few days. We often also stop to explore the old miner’s camp at Powerhouse Rapids. Today is a good day to keep your eyes open for the nest of the playful American Dipper, a small gray bird that swims underwater and builds its nest above fast-flowing water often in the middle of a rapid. We have plenty of fun rapids as the river continues its quick descent. At lunch we take out the inflatable kayaks for those seeking a more intimate experience with the river. We stop for a soak in Sunflower Flat Hot Springs with pools above the river that cascade over a rocky cliff to create nature’s perfect shower. We make camp around 4:00pm and enjoy hiking, fishing and relaxing. After dinner the night sky is brilliant with stars and planets the welcome stories and wonder.

We’ve dropped over 1,500 feet in elevation so our days and nights are warmer. The fir and spruce make way for towering ponderosa pines, sagebrush and riparian hardwoods. The gin-clear water carries us swiftly along as the river channel widens and narrows due to the underlying geology. One of today's highlights is stopping to view pictographs of the Native American Tukudeka, or Sheepeater Indians who lived in this canyon until the 1870’s. The afternoon is most relaxing as the canyon widens and the current slows. We learn about early pioneers and their colorful stories. Lunch is often accompanied by a short walk or swim. By latter afternoon we arrive to camp near Loon Creek, about 50 miles from our starting point. A highlight here is a hike to the Loon Creek hot springs. Summer evenings are long, with darkness arriving around 9:30pm or even 10:00pm in June and July. The night sky, crackling campfire and fresh mountain air will help you sleep like a baby.

This is yet another great day of active rapids and incredible Rocky Mountain scenery. We often see big horn sheep attracted to natural licks along the river where they find important minerals. Those fishing will continue to do well with the bountiful trout and birdwatchers are likely to see falcons, songbirds and golden eagles. We pass our last hot spring at Hospital Bar, so named because early cattlemen let their stock rest and feed at this large flat and easy ford across the river. Continuing on we raft through the Tappan series of rapids. This is a great photo opportunity with plenty of splashes and thrills. The final miles to camp offer a chance to lean back and take in the awe-inspiring scenery of the River of No Return Wilderness.

The river carries us through more astounding scenery and late morning we run Haystack Rapid, the most dynamic rapid on the river. This is the official start of Impassable Canyon as the canyon narrows and deepens creating a series of action-packed rapids. A favorite stop is at Waterfall Creek, where a steep trail leads up to the Bighorn Crags. We walk beneath the falls and on hot days finish with a jump into the river. Shortly downstream the river has made a deep incision into the Idaho batholith – the largest monolithic chunk of granite in North America and you look up for neck-bending panoramas. Further downstream we hike to the base of Veil Falls, a soul-stirring cavern with pictographs and magic. By the end of the day you will have seen some of the most beautiful wild scenery on earth. Once at camp, the silhouette of canyon walls against the night sky will captivate you as you reflect, celebrate and share with newfound friends on your last night on the Middle Fork.

As we push off from shore we float past the hideout of the legendary Earl Parrot, Hermit of Impassable Canyon. His story is as big as the canyon and adds just one more thread of wonder to your rafting experience. As the sun breaks over the canyon rim, more big rapids greet us as we pass beneath vistas of staggering dimensions. As we near the end of our 100-mile journey, we stop to enjoy lunch on a glistening sand beach just above the Middle Fork's confluence with the Main Salmon. We continue to our takeout, carry personal gear to the waiting bus and settle back for a two-hour ride to the town of Salmon. After you enjoy a hot shower and find a change of clothes we meet for a celebratory hosted farewell dinner.

If you drove to Stanley and had your car shuttled, it is waiting for you at the hotel. If you are flying home, you'll board an air taxi for the one-hour flight back to Boise to connect home. A nice extension to consider would be north to Glacier National Park or southeast to Yellowstone National Park.

tourName: San Francisco to LA tour, USA
generalInfo: San Francisco and Los Angeles are two of the most well-known locations in the USA… but what’s in between? This 13-day trip takes you from the shores of San Francisco to the bustling streets of La La Land via Nevada, Arizona and Utah. See desert landscapes, expansive national parks and the world-famous Grand Canyon! If you want to experience the buzz of the big city mixed with the adventure of forests, cliffs and canyons, this trip has all your bases covered. Journey through the west coast on a classic North American road trip with the flexibility to go with the flow.

dayInfo.title: San Francisco.
dayInfo.description: Welcome to California! Your adventure begins in San Francisco – The City by the Bay that boasts a beautiful setting and a vibrant, multicultural heart. You’ll have a welcome meeting at 6 pm tonight, followed by an optional group dinner. If you arrive early, maybe check out the vintage stores along funky Haight Street, catch the tram down to the waterfront or take an adventure cruise on the bay past Alcatraz Island. Better yet, consider booking an Urban Adventures sightseeing tour like Bridge and the Beach, where you’ll see a different side of the Golden Gate from Baker Beach.

dayInfo.title: Yosemite National Park.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll drive into the heart of the Sierra Nevada Mountains to your destination – the magnificent Yosemite National Park. Passing by serene vistas, you’ll catch a glimpse of one of Yosemite’s most recognisable features – Half Dome. You'll spend three nights camping near Yosemite National Park so that there are two full days available to explore at your own pace.

dayInfo.title: Yosemite National Park.
dayInfo.description: Today is free to discover the wonders of the park. One of the most famous parks in the USA, Yosemite boasts colossal granite cliffs, cascading waterfalls and redwood forests that attract visitors worldwide. The leader will point you in the right direction from the village before leaving you to spend the day as you please. There are plenty of hikes available, each varying in steepness and difficulty. Maybe hike under the cooling breezes of Nevada Falls (4 to 5 hours) or to the serene Mirror Lake (45 minutes). Keep an eye out for squirrels and bears along the way. You might prefer to hire a bike and explore Yosemite Valley. You can also visit the park's museum, photo gallery, shops and restaurants, and in the heat of summer, a relaxing float down the Merced River is highly recommended.

dayInfo.title: Yosemite National Park.
dayInfo.description: With a second full day in the park, there’s an opportunity to explore a different side of Yosemite. Your leader will take you on a guided hike to Hetch Hetchy – an often overlooked, elevated valley in the park’s northwest corner. It has a floor elevation of 1150 m (or 3800 feet), and one of the main characteristics is its man-made reservoir, built in the early 20th century. The area attracts far fewer visitors than the more well-known Yosemite hiking points, and its remoteness makes it the ideal place to discover cascading waterfalls and beautiful wildflowers.

dayInfo.title: Sierra Nevada / Keough Hot Springs.
dayInfo.description: Depart Yosemite via the Tioga Pass this morning, stopping at Mono Lake on the way. The Sierra Nevadas are sandwiched between Central Valley and Death Valley – this is a scenic trip that will take you to the town of Bishop, where you’ll camp the night and visit some nearby natural hot springs. In town, maybe go to Erick Schat’s European-style bakery for a delicious treat, or stop in tomorrow for a coffee and cake on the way to the glitz of Vegas.

dayInfo.title: Las Vegas.
dayInfo.description: Drive to the original sin city this morning – Las Vegas, Nevada. Vegas may be known for its casinos and late-night antics, but there's plenty to do if gambling isn't your thing. Hit the shops, see a world-class stage show, feel your stomach drop on a rooftop roller-coaster or stroll along Freemont Street, soaking up this neon-filled desert city. If you plan to see a show, remember that tickets can sell out quickly for popular shows, so it’s best to book before your tour begins.

dayInfo.title: Las Vegas.
dayInfo.description: With another day in Las Vegas, you can continue to discover all things over-the-top. Food-focused travellers may want to check out one of the celebrity chef restaurants around town (Giada De Laurentiis, Gordon Ramsay and Wolfgang Puck all have places here). See the Eiffel Tower of the USA, check out the Bellagio Fountains or visit one of the wacky museums. If you didn’t head out last night, chat to your leader for the lowdown on sin city's best shows, clubs and restaurants and the option of hiring a limo for the night. You might as well go all out in Las Vegas, right?

dayInfo.title: Zion National Park.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll drive from Vegas to Zion National Park – a nature preserve in Utah famous for its steep red cliffs and scenic drive that leads to forest trails along the Virgin River. When you arrive, you have free time to explore the park. Maybe you’d like to take on one of the popular hikes this afternoon – your leader is always on hand with the best recommendations. Tonight, you’ll be camping near the park so it’s a good opportunity to unplug, do a spot of star gazing and listen to the sounds of nature.

dayInfo.title: Bryce Canyon National Park.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll head out on a scenic drive from Zion to Bryce Canyon National Park – another reserve known for its crimson-coloured hoodoos (spire-shaped rock formations). Along the drive, you’ll explore the park’s popular road stops for the best overlooks. When you arrive, you have some free time, so maybe head out on a hike or explore at your own pace. Tonight, you’ll spend another night camping near the park.

dayInfo.title: Grand Canyon National Park.
dayInfo.description: This morning you’ll drive to Grand Cayon National Park – a must-see for any USA adventure! When you arrive, get ready to admire a natural wonder formed by over six million years of erosion by the Colorado River. When you think about the canyon’s dimensions – 450 km long, 630 km wide and 1600 m deep – it really does warrant the ‘grand’ title. You’ll spend two nights here, which allows for a full day of exploration tomorrow. Check out the park’s massive scale on a walk around the rim or, if you’re feeling more active, hike into the canyon itself to stretch your legs.

dayInfo.title: Grand Canyon National Park.
dayInfo.description: Today is a free day to explore the Grand Canyon and all its beauty. Stroll along the meandering South Rim Trail or hike your way down to Plateau Point. In the early evening, relax at the canyon's edge and enjoy a spectacular sunset over one the world's best natural wonders.

dayInfo.title: Joshua Tree National Park.
dayInfo.description: This morning, leave the canyon behind and travel along the famous Route 66, stopping in Seligman along the way – a quirky small town that features a vibrant slice of retro America. After wandering around the shops and old-school diners, continue your road trip to Joshua Tree. Sitting between the Mojave and Colorado Deserts, the Joshua Tree is famous for its spectacular desert plants, cacti and spiky trees, bizarre rock formations and a pretty good U2 album. After a wander through the park, you’ll head to Lake Havasu on the Colorado River (at the Arizona border) and check in to your hotel for the night. You might like to head out on a scenic hike around the town, learn the backstory of the city’s unique London Bridge, or even take a refreshing dip in the Colorado River.

dayInfo.title: Los Angeles.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll drive to Los Angeles, where your trip comes to an end. If you’d like to extend your stay, just speak to your booking agent.

tourName: Self drive tour of the National Parks of America
placesVisited: Travel through six states: Colorado, Wyoming, South Dakota, Arizona, Utah and New Mexico, Denver, Cheyenne, bison in Thunder Basin National Grassland, Custer State Park, Jewel Cave National Monument, Mount Rushmore and Crazy Horse National Monuments, Sheridan, wild horses in Bighorn National Park, Cody, Yellowstone National Park, Grand Teton National Park, Jackson, Salt Lake City, Fishlake National Forest, Bryce Canyon National Park, Zion National Park, Lake Powell, Monument Valley Navajo Tribal Park, Mesa Verde National Park, Rio Grande National Forest, Alamosa, Colorado Springs
generalInfo:
Set off on a three-week self drive tour of the national parks of America, exploring rugged landscapes, discovering Native American culture, and enjoying lots of time in the great outdoors. You’ll travel through six different states and although guided by an itinerary, you’re free to explore at your own pace.

In Arizona, see hills punctuated by tall cacti and explore Monument Valley. In Utah, Zion National Park is a wonderful place for walking and in Colorado, where this tour begins, you’ll find spectacular mountain ranges, iconic Monument Valley, and the Puebloan Indian houses of Mesa Verde National Park. Wyoming, further north from here, is all about cowboy culture of the Wild West, characterised by never-ending grasslands and tiny Western towns. Over in South Dakota, see the landmark memorials of Crazy Horse and Mount Rushmore, and discover the Native American heritage here. You’ll also spend time in iconic Yellowstone National park, a place of spurting geysers and abundant wildlife. Other highlights include Grand Teton National Park, home to huge peaks, deep lakes and buzzing town of Jackson.

dayInfo.description: International Outbound Flight - Denver. Today you will begin your journey by boarding your international outbound flight to Denver. On arrival in Denver make your own way to your downtown hotel. The remainder of the day is free to relax.

Denver. Enjoy a day exploring the highlights of Denver. Don't miss the Denver Art Museum, the Colorado History Museum or explore the city's many excellent art galleries. Alternatively, relax in Larimer Square and sample some excellent local cuisine while people watching.

Denver - Cheyenne. Pick up your hire car and drive north past Roosevelt National Forest to the town of Cheyenne, just across the border into Wyoming. Cheyenne still exudes the atmosphere of the Wild West. Be sure to visit the Wyoming State Museum and the Union Pacific Railway terminus.
Cheyenne - Custer. Travel north from Cheyenne to Custer State Park in South Dakota. You may wish to visit Thunder Basin National Grassland en route which offers excellent bison watching.

Custer. Spend the morning looking for bison on the grassy plains of Custer State Park or visiting the remarkable geological feature of Jewel Cave National Monument. A highlight of the region are Mount Rushmore and Crazy Horse national monuments, indelibly carved from the natural rock.

Custer - Sheridan. Leaving Custer, you may wish to visit the old Wild West town of Deadwood and Devil's Tower National Monument before continuing on to Sheridan. The afternoon is free to explore this fascinating Western town.
Sheridan - Cody. Travel west from Sheridan to Cody. Do ensure you spend some time exploring Bighorn National Park where herds of wild horses roam amid spectacular mountain scenery.

Cody - Yellowstone National Park. Your drive today takes you in to Yellowstone National Park. The scenery gets ever more spectacular as you approach Yellowstone Lake. Do ensure you keep a look out for wildlife which thrives here.

Yellowstone National Park. Enjoy a full day in Yellowstone. This magnificent park offers a wide range of activities such as walking, canoeing and mountain biking. Be sure to visit "Old Faithful", the park's renowned geyser, as well as the colourfully-hued lakes, boiling mud and sulphurous springs. Elk, bison, antelope and wolves abound so do keep your camera handy.

Yellowstone National Park - Jackson WY - Grand Teton National Park. Leaving Yellowstone, drive south through magnificent mountain scenery to Grand Teton National Park. The afternoon is free to explore the little town of Jackson or go walking, boating, cycling or horse-riding.

Jackson, WY - Grand Teton National Park. Grand Teton National Park awaits your discovery today. You may wish to visit beautiful Jackson Lake, take a boat trip on picturesque Lewis Lake or look for wildlife in the mountains and forests. Don't miss a guided wildlife discovery trip into Grand Teton National Park to learn about the region's fascinating flora, fauna, geology and history.

Jackson, WY - Grand Teton National Park , Salt Lake City. Depart Grand Teton National Park and drive south along the banks of the Uinta Wasatch Cache National Forest to Salt Lake City. The afternoon is free for you to explore this lovely city.

Salt Lake City. You have a full day today to explore the great city of Salt Lake City. You may wish to take a hike in Big Cottonwood Canyon, visit Red Butte Gardens or the Mormon temple or simply enjoy the eclectic shops and the pavement cafés.

Salt Lake City - Bryce Canyon National Park. Drive from Salt Lake City through Fishlake National Forest to the magnificent Bryce Canyon National Park. Be sure to visit Bryce Canyon's magnificent scenery which is especially beautiful at sunset.

Bryce Canyon National Park , Springdale - Zion National Park. Drive through spectacular red rock mountain vistas as you wind your way south towards Zion National Park. The afternoon is free to explore the little town of Springfield, lying at the gateway to Zion National Park, or exploring the park itself.

Springdale - Zion National Park. Spend a full day in Zion National Park. There are many activities available and some truly magnificent mountain scenery to explore. You may wish to take a hike to the Narrows, the Emerald Pools or walk one of the many trails.

Springdale - Zion National Park. Drive from Zion National Park into Arizona. This route takes you through wonderful forest scenery through the town of Kanab to Page on the edge of Lake Powell. You may wish to take a boat trip on the lake this afternoon.

Page - Monument Valley Navajo Tribal Park Drive from Page to Monument Valley where you have the afternoon free to explore this incredible landscape. Be sure to take a Navajo-guided tour through the valley to learn all about its flora, fauna, geology and Navajo history.

Monument Valley Navajo Tribal Park - Mesa Verde National Park. Leaving Monument Valley, drive east through New Mexico and into Colorado. Be sure to stop at some of the many marvellous Ancestral Pueblo Indians sites along the way, such as Hovenweep National Monument. Your destination is the stunning Mesa Verde National Park.

Mesa Verde National Park. Mesa Verde National Park awaits your discovery today. Visit the Ancient Pueblo Indian dwellings of the National Park to learn all about this fascinating civilisation and be amazed at their stunning cliff dwellings. You may also wish to hike the trails that lead through this excellent national park.
Mesa Verde National Park - Alamosa. Today your drive takes you through the heart of Colorado and the Rio Grande National Forest to the pretty town of Alamosa.

Alamosa - Colorado Springs. Drive past California Peak, the most southerly in the Great Sand Dunes National Park, and through the town of Pueblo, arriving at Colorado Springs where the remainder of the afternoon is free to explore.

Colorado Springs - International Return Flight There is time this morning for last minute shopping and sightseeing before driving back to Denver and returning your hire car at the airport prior to boarding your onward flight.
International Return Flight. Arrive home today to complete your journey.

tourName: Snake River rafting holiday in Hells Canyon, North America
generalInfo:
A rafting holiday on the Snake River in Hells Canyon is a trip of superlatives. Hells Canyon was carved by the powerful Snake River and is North America's deepest gorge at nearly 8,000 feet. The river canyon forms the border between Oregon and Idaho and is primarily inaccessible by road. Floating through Hells Canyon offers spectacular views of towering mountains and an immersion into remote regions of Idaho and Oregon wilderness areas. There is abundant wildlife to see including black bear, big horn sheep, river otter, golden eagles and more. Fishing is excellent for trout and bass. Finally, the thrilling Class III-IV white water rapids make the Snake River in Hells Canyon a world-famous river rafting adventure holiday.

Our Snake River rafting adventures through Hells Canyon pass through the traditional lands of the Nez Perce Indians, a land that is both rich in myth as well as geologic wonder. The river runs from south to north, cutting through some of the most rugged, impressive landscape on earth. From various side creeks, boulders and rock slides have rolled into the river creating the biggest white water rafting rapids in the Pacific Northwest of the United States. There are high-crested waves and raft-swallowing holes that drench you in white water excitement.

Between the rapids, there is plenty of time to relax and gaze upon snow-capped peaks that tower more than a mile above. There are mountainsides covered in golden grass and pine forests and it is common to see roaming bears, grazing deer, soaring eagles, or wild mountain goats.

Some people come to raft the Snake River for the excellent fishing. Species include trout, smallmouth bass and North America's largest freshwater fish, the white sturgeon. Others come to learn more about the history of the Native Americans who lived here for thousands of years and to view their rock art. There are also early American homesteads remaining as a graphic example of the settling of the American West. Everyone enjoys swimming in the near-70-degree water, camping under the stars and sharing the wonders of Hells Canyon.

On these trips you have a choice of riding in oar-powered rafts with a guide who does all the work while you simply enjoy the ride and taking photos; riding in a paddle raft where you are part of team paddling along with your guide who gives directions or; paddling your own inflatable kayak. We have a cargo raft that travels ahead of the group and sets up a deluxe camp including your tent, a complete kitchen with dining tables and chairs and more. Food served along the way is excellent, all packed in large coolers on ice using the best-available fresh ingredients. We provide one guide per three to four guests ensuring a high level of quality personal service.

Three to six day trips are offered depending on the month. It’s also possible to combine this trip with another whitewater river such as the Lochsa, or a stay at our own Idaho guest ranch.

dayInfo.description: Travel from your home to Boise, capital city of Idaho. Boise is easily accessible via Salt Lake City and other major airline hubs. From Boise we transfer you two hours to the small town of Cambridge, Idaho where we meet at a local motel at 7:00 PM Mountain Standard Time (MST). We have an orientation meeting to answer any last-minute questions and give you your waterproof gear bags. Dinner is on your own.

Meet your guide at 7:30am for a two-hour bus ride to the put-in on the Snake River. We stop along the way for a hosted breakfast. Our launching point is at the base of Hells Canyon Dam, about 1,500 feet above sea level. There we have a thorough safety briefing while personal gear is loaded. The briefing covers how to paddle, how to ride in a raft, how to swim through rapids, and other important advice for the days ahead. Once complete, everyone chooses a raft and climbs aboard. The Snake River has “pool and drop” characteristics which means that there is a long pool of calm water followed by a rapid. Before long after we launch we run several fun Hells Canyon rapids that are a great roller coaster ride and taste of what is to come. After an hour or so, we stop for a riverside lunch and some guides prepare the meal while others give a “camp orientation” to explain how we minimize our impact on the river. ROW adheres to "Leave No Trace" camping ethics, so you learn how and where to wash up, how our toilet system works, where to brush your teeth, put trash and recyclables, etc. Then come to the table to make a sandwich and eat a hearty meal in this open-air dining experience. Typically we raft two big class IV rapids the first day – Wild Sheep and Granite. These immense and impressive rapids never fail to get everyone’s heart pumping. This is also a good day for fishing as the water is cooler at this elevation and fishing for trout in the tail waters of the rapids is excellent. About 4:00pm we get to camp which is all set up by our crew and raft that have traveled ahead. You have plenty of time for hiking, reading, fishing, or simply relaxing. Hors d’oeuvres are served around 6:00 and dinner around 7:30. It stays light until past 10 in June and July but finally the evening sky grows dark and the first stars appear. With no interference from city lights the stars are extremely bright and invite contemplation on the day and conversation with friends, new and old.

We wake you about 7:00am by bringing coffee to your tent, or your choice of tea or cocoa. Breakfast is served around 7:30, and afterwards, while we clean up the kitchen, you pack up your personal gear. We depart camp about 9:30 for a continuation of your Snake River rafting holiday. This is an exciting day of rapids, sun and dramatic scenery. We stop to explore a homesteader's cabin, root cellar and farm implements that give you a glimpse into what pioneer life would have been like a century ago. We continue on with more Snake River whitewater rafting. At times the river mellows and you can jump in and float along with the rafts. The mountains tower above as the hot sun shines down. There are over a hundred Native American rock art sites along the Snake River in Hells Canyon and during the trip we stop to looks at several. This is a unique and special place because we find both pictographs (rock paintings) and petroglyphs (rock carvings) left by the different tribes that traveled the canyon including both the Nez Perce and Shoshone. We camp tonight in the Salt Creek area, likely on a sandy beach. After dinner, another delightful evening awaits with time to share the day’s events with new friends under a gorgeous night sky.

One of the highlights of today is a hike along the river trail at Suicide Point. High above the river are stunning view of sweeping panoramas. We return to the rafts, and the Snake carries us to our next stop. We pull ashore at the Kirkwood Historic Ranch which not long ago was a working sheep ranch. We visit the blacksmith shop, water system, sheering shed, and homestead cabins. Before the creation of the Hells Canyon National Recreation Area in 1976, this ranch had thousands of sheep grazing in the surrounding mountains. We continue down river and the canyon opens up as we arrive at Pittsburg Landing, somtimes take a short hike to see one of the richest collections of Indian petroglyphs on the Snake. Then continue past Pittsburg Landing. Soon after the river narrows and the canyon's beauty intensifies. At camp each evening our guides often set up horseshoes or guide a hike. We feast on another healthy and nutritious meal, enjoy sharing stories and then the night sky and fresh mountain air help you sleep soundly to the quiet rush of the river’s song.

Today, in addition to the spectacular scenery and whitewater, there are some intriguing history lessons. We pass by the river crossing used by Chief Joseph and the Wallowa band of the Nez Perce Indians during their 1877 forced exodus from their homeland. At a place called China Creek our guides weave the story about a massacre of Chinese miners who were thought to have had a large cache of gold. The human drama in Hells Canyon is certainly as interesting as the many natural wonders we discover including the abundant wildlife, flora and geology. After another full day of river rafting fun and discovery brings us to camp for more exploring, dinner and finally, sleeping.

We continue downriver in our rafts and gaze upon more dramatic scenery. Between the exciting rapids, we look for golden eagles soaring overhead. At Eureka Bar you learn about the copper mines at and the past era of steamboats that travelled along this river. In the afternoon we come to the confluence with the legendary Salmon “River of No Return.” From here on we are carried along on double the volume of water as compared to just the Snake River alone. Tonight we camp on a large, white sand beach where there is time for playing on the beach, taking a hike above camp to take photos, relax and sunbath or whatever you might want. Then it’s time for yet another perfect evening of laughter and camaraderie under a big Western star-studded sky.

By now you are completely adjusted to “river time” and wake up to welcome a new day of adventure. There are some big waves and big rides on this section of the Snake River as well as some long stretches of flat water. Depending on the river flow, we may join the rafts together and use a small, quiet outboard motor to cover some of the day’s miles. As we travel downstream, we float by a mountainside where the original Nez Perce trail descends into the canyon to a crossing place used for centuries by the Nez Perce as they traveled east from the Wallowa Mountains (in today’s northeast corner of Oregon) on their way to fish the Salmon River, or go even farther to the plains of Montana to hunt buffalo. We stop for lunch on a sandy beach and take time for a group photo. After a few more miles of magnificent scenery we reach our ending point just past the Snake River's confluence with the Grande Ronde River. Gear is untied and everyone carries their personal gear to the waiting bus and then we take a 45-minute ride back to the town of Lewiston, Idaho. At the motel enjoy a hot shower, change clothes and then we meet for a hosted dinner at a local restaurant.

If you drove to Cambridge and had your car shuttled north, it's waiting for you at the hotel. If you are flying, there’s a free shuttle from the hotel to the Lewiston airport. Or you can take a taxi two hours north to the Spokane airport which sometimes offers more reasonable airfares than Lewiston.

tourName: South Carolina self drive holiday in USA
generalInfo:
This 12-day custom itinerary begins in Charleston, one of the South’s most vibrant and historical cities. Well-known for its pastel-coloured antebellum houses, swaying palm trees and a lovingly preserved low-level skyline with no buildings higher than a church-spire, the city has a storied past that is best discovered on foot.

Two hours away lies the low-country resort of Montage Palmetto Bluff, a nature-lovers haven for the well-heeled traveller. Spend a few days exploring the pristine waterways that surround the resort and learn about the ecology of the area by boat, bicycle or walking with a resident naturalist. You will have the opportunity to observe native birdlife including wood stork, roseate spoonbill and egret as well as wild dolphin playing amongst the marshes. You should also keep an eye out for the alligators that peruse the resort’s natural lagoons.

From the quaint town of Bluffton, you will drive on to Hilton Head Island, a coastal gem with white sand beaches, an abundance of diverse wildlife and miles of protected shoreline. You can visit the Pickney Island National Wildlife Refuge to spot heron and white-tailed deer or hike through Sea Pines Forest Preserve. We also recommend visiting the Coastal Discovery Museum, where you can learn all about the sea turtles that nest and hatch on the beaches of Hilton Head. With the temptation to drive for hundreds of miles on a road-trip in America, this is a single-state itinerary that slows you down to experience the raw natural beauty of one of America’s lesser visited states by international tourists.

dayInfo.description: Begin your journey by boarding your international flight to Charleston, SC. On arrival in Charleston, you will make your own way to your hotel. The rest of the evening is yours to enjoy. Why not take a stroll up neighboring King Street and enjoy dinner at a local restaurant

After a leisurely breakfast, you will head out for the day to meet your local guide for a walking tour of Charleston. Knowledgeable and friendly, your guide will tell tales of the Revolutionary and Civil wars, as well as give you insider tips on the best spots to eat and drink in Charleston. Your guide can also give you recommendations for museums if you wish to further develop your knowledge of the city’s history. Later that afternoon, you may wish to visit the Old Slave Mart Museum, Fort Sumter or one of the antebellum houses, once lived in by a wealthy family.

The day is yours to enjoy. Visit a nearby plantation on the outskirts of Charleston along the May River Road, peruse the boutiques of King Street or take a culinary tour of the city’s best restaurants.

Picking up your rental car, drive two hours south to the town of Bluffton, where you will find Montage Palmetto Bluff. Time it right, and you can say hello to the resident pups at check-in before being shown to your lagoon view room. Take in the surroundings on your porch and see if you can spot one of the alligators who live in the lagoon before heading out for dinner. Be sure to stop by the fire-pit and the s’mores cart before retiring for the night.

This morning, explore by bicycle and admire the salt-marsh landscape that surrounds the resort. Enjoy lunch by the pool, and then head down to the pier for your eco-boat tour out on the water. Search for wild dolphins and keep your eyes to the sky to admire resident birdlife.

Spend another day at leisure at the Bluff. Take your pick from a variety of activities on offer, from kayaking out to a remote sand-bar to visiting fascinating Daufuskie Island to learn about Gullah culture, there is plenty to enjoy.

Say goodbye to the Bluff and head into town to learn about the historic churches and buildings that are preserved here. Take a stroll to the general store to pick up some souvenirs and enjoy a fresh fruit smoothie at one of the independent cafes. Then, take the short 15-minute drive to Hilton Head Island and enjoy an afternoon at the beach.

Rise early and head to the Pickney Island National Wildlife Refuge, where you can explore over 14 miles of hiking trails. Brightly coloured painted buntings are easily spotted in the summer months, but be sure to bring binoculars to spot more elusive birds – there are over 250 in the refuge. The refuge is also one of the best places in the state to see yellow-crowned night herons. Those looking for an active day can hike to White Point, where you will be rewarded with a small, pristine beach as well as sweeping views of the water – the hike is 7.8 miles round-trip.

Today, visit the Coastal Discovery Museum to learn about sea turtles and in the afternoon, visit the Harbor Town Lighthouse to view artefacts from island's historic eras. Once you reach the top of the lighthouse, you will be rewarded with panoramic views over the island's landscape.

Soak up the Carolina sunshine on the beach today, or for more active travelers, head to the Sea Pines Forest Preserve for hiking trails. You may also wish to rent a kayak and explore the waterways and creeks surrounding the island.

Spend your last day catching some rays by visiting one of the many beaches on the island. You will have the day to relax before driving back to Charleston to drop your car off and catch your overnight flight home.
Arrive home today to complete your journey.

tourName: USA's Deep South small group holiday
generalInfo:
This trip traces its way through America's iconic Deep South. From North Carolina's Appalachian mountains to the Mississippi River Delta and New Orleans; explore the music, food and deeply rich culture of this eclectic corner of the US.
Asheville - Walk amongst the towering trees of North Carolina's State Parks and visit a craft brewery
Nashville - Explore the home of country music and the city's honkey-tonk bars
